channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: I Went Home to Texas to Cover the Virus. Then My Family Got It.
item.description: Edgar Sandoval knew he was well prepared to report on the spread of the coronavirus on the Texas-Mexico border. He was going home. Little did he know exactly what he would find.
item.dc:creator: Edgar Sandoval
item.media:credit: Ilana Panich-Linsman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A masked mannequin in a dress shop in McAllen, Texas. Hidalgo County, which includes McAllen, reported 1,274 new cases of the coronavirus on Thursday, setting a record.

item.title: Navy Warship Is Still Ablaze, and Now Tilting to One Side
item.description: The U.S.S. Bonhomme Richard in San Diego is listing because of water from the fire hoses, tugboats and helicopters fighting the inferno, which has destroyed the ship’s forward mast.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay and Richard A. Oppel Jr.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Mike Blake/Reuters
item.media:description: U.S. Navy helicopters continue fighting a fire on the amphibious assault ship U.S.S. Bonhomme Richard at Naval Base San Diego on Monday.

item.title: The Massacre That Destroyed Tulsa’s ‘Black Wall Street’
item.description: In 1921, the city of Tulsa erupted in a spasm of hate and fire that destroyed its prosperous Black district. A century later, excavators are uncovering a “crime scene.”
item.dc:creator: Ben Fenwick
item.media:credit: Joseph Rushmore for The New York Times
item.media:description: A forensic team on Monday began to remove earth from an 8-by-4-foot test dig in an effort that was expected to last about a week. Researchers are focusing on what is described as an “anomaly” in the ground, which could mean the earth there was disturbed.

item.title: ‘We’re Not an Island’: Rural Outbreaks Challenge Oregon’s Virus Success
item.description: Oregon was sandwiched between two states that had big coronavirus outbreaks but managed to keep its numbers low. Until it couldn’t.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger
item.media:credit: Mark Ylen/Albany Democrat-Herald, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Members of the Oregon National Guard prepared masks to be distributed to farmers in Tangent, Ore. Rural areas in the state are seeing an uptick in cases of the coronavirus, and cities are now at risk, too.

item.title: Live Trump vs Biden 2020 Updates
item.description: With Tommy Tuberville defeating Jeff Sessions to be the party’s Senate nominee in Alabama, Republicans are now focusing on two closely watched races next door.
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Victory Gardens Were More About Solidarity Than Survival
item.description: During World War II, millions of Americans grew their own vegetables, but the movement was driven much more by government and corporate messaging than by the threat of starvation.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Steinhauer

item.title: Sessions Falls in Alabama, and Gideon Rises in Maine
item.description: Alabama sides with Trump, and anti-G.O.P. energy builds in Maine: This is your morning tip sheet.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello

item.title: The Legacy of the First Nuclear Bomb Test
item.description: The 75th anniversary of what’s known as the Trinity explosion, the world’s first nuclear weapon test, comes as tensions over nuclear devices intensify.
item.dc:creator: Maria Cramer
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Associated Press
item.media:description: An aerial view of the aftermath of the first atomic explosion at the Trinity test site in New Mexico in 1945. The device exploded with a power equivalent to 21,000 tons of TNT.

item.title: A Different Cold War
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times

item.title: Coronavirus Live Updates: Virus Resurgence Threatens U.S. Economy
item.description: The Trump administration ordered hospitals to bypass the C.D.C. with key virus data. Childhood vaccination rates worldwide continue to plunge.
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: ‘Coming Out of the Woodwork’: Black Lives Matter in Small-Town America
item.description: A multiracial future has appeared, along with unprecedented conversations about race.
item.dc:creator: Campbell Robertson
item.media:credit: Valerie Plesch for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters gathered at the main square in downtown Chambersburg, Pa., for the Juneteenth Love Demonstration held on June 20.

item.title: ‘Just Let Those Kids Dance’: Finding a Way for the Show to Go On
item.description: For dance students, the annual recital is the biggest event of the year. Whether in parks or in parking lots, some studios are determined to make it happen in a pandemic year.
item.dc:creator: Julia Jacobs
item.media:credit: Angelo Silvio Vasta for The New York Times

item.title: A Resurgence of the Virus, and Lockdowns, Threatens Economic Recovery
item.description: Hopes for a rebound are endangered by prolonged closures of schools, renewed state restrictions on business and fears of a difficult autumn and winter.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley and Ben Casselman
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: The front doors of Public School 23 in the Bronx. New York officials are preparing to bring students back for only part-time instruction in the fall.

item.title: Trump to Weaken Environmental Rules to Speed Infrastructure Permits
item.description: President Trump has used a regulatory reinterpretation to limit one of the country's bedrock environmental laws and speed permitting of infrastructure projects.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Brandon Thibodeaux for The New York Times
item.media:description: A view of the Motiva refinery looking over the rooftops of home in Port Arthur, Texas, in April.

item.title: New Twists on Home-Sharing: 4 Airbnb Alternatives
item.description: They are small, ambitious and target savvy travelers. But their main goal is to improve the home-sharing experience for hosts and renters alike.
item.dc:creator: Elaine Glusac

item.title: Ronny Jackson, Ex-White House Doctor, Wins Texas House Runoff
item.description: Dr. Jackson, a Republican who was backed by President Trump and based his campaign around their close relationship, effectively stamped his ticket to Congress in a deep-red district.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ronny Jackson, the former White House doctor, left the West Wing in December and went home to Texas.

item.title: Representative Steve Watkins of Kansas Is Charged With Voter Fraud
item.description: Three felony charges were filed against Steve Watkins, a Republican, shortly before he appeared in a televised debate ahead of the state’s primary election.
item.dc:creator: Will Wright
item.media:credit: House Television, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Representative Steve Watkins speaking at the Capitol in December. On Tuesday, he said the charges were “clearly hyper-political.”

item.title: Sara Gideon Wins Democratic Nomination in Maine to Challenge Susan Collins
item.description: Ms. Gideon, backed by the Senate Democratic campaign arm and outside political groups, had long been the favorite to challenge Senator Collins, the sole remaining New England Republican in Congress.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane
item.media:credit: Robert F. Bukaty/Associated Press
item.media:description: Sara Gideon, the speaker of the Maine State House, at a campaign event in Skowhegan. She has raised $23 million from both voters in Maine and national Democratic donors.

item.title: Sessions Pays the Price for Incurring Trump’s Wrath, Losing Alabama Senate Race
item.description: In Maine, Sara Gideon prevailed over limited competition in the Democratic primary for Senate and will face Susan Collins in a race that has become the priciest Senate campaign in the state’s history.
item.dc:creator: Elaina Plott and Jonathan Martin
item.media:credit: September Dawn Bottoms/The New York Times
item.media:description: Jeff Sessions competed for the Senate seat he once held before becoming President Trump’s first Attorney General.

item.title: Why Sessions' Campaigning in Alabama Couldn't Overcome Trump
item.description: He beat back tears. He said he let his family down. He declared of politics, “This chapter of my life is closed.” But he would not criticize his former boss, and even said President Trump could win in November.
item.dc:creator: Elaina Plott
item.media:credit: September Dawn Bottoms/The New York Times
item.media:description: Jeff Sessions entered the Senate primary in large part, it seemed, as a way to reset his political career on his own terms.

item.title: The White House Called a News Conference. Trump Turned It Into a Meandering Monologue.
item.description: The president spoke in the Rose Garden for 63 minutes. He spent only six of those minutes answering questions from reporters.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: Even for those who follow President Trump regularly and understand his shorthand, it became challenging to follow his train of thought during a news conference on Tuesday.

item.title: Trump Says, ‘So Are White People,’ When Asked About Black Americans Killed by Police
item.description: The president rejected the fact that Black people suffer disproportionately from police brutality and made startling remarks about the Confederate flag and a recent confrontation in St. Louis.
item.dc:creator: Jeremy W. Peters
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump at the Rose Garden on Tuesday. He reacted angrily when asked during an interview with CBS News about police killings of Black people.

item.title: Trump Administration Strips C.D.C. of Control of Coronavirus Data
item.description: Hospitals have been ordered to bypass the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and send all patient information to a central database in Washington, raising questions about transparency.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: A scientist at Houston Methodist Hospital last month preparing patient samples to be tested for the coronavirus.

item.title: Ruth Bader Ginsburg Is Hospitalized With a Possible Infection
item.description: Justice Ginsburg, 87, underwent an endoscopic procedure at the Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore to clean out a bile duct stent, a Supreme Court spokeswoman said.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.category: Notorious RBG: The Life and Times of Ruth Bader Ginsburg (Book)
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.media:description: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg in Washington last year.

item.title: Naya Rivera’s Death Ruled Accidental Drowning
item.description: No traumatic injuries or disease were found, the medical examiner said.
item.dc:creator: Aimee Ortiz and Johnny Diaz
item.media:credit: Willy Sanjuan/Invision, via Willy Sanjuan, via Invision, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Naya Rivera during a panel in 2018. She made her acting debut as a 4-year-old on the 1991 CBS sitcom “The Royal Family.”

item.title: Blaine Kern, Architect of Lavish Mardi Gras Floats, Dies at 93
item.description: The work of Mr. Kern, known as “Mr. Mardi Gras,” has delighted visitors to Carnival in New Orleans for decades.
item.dc:creator: Steven Kurutz
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times
item.media:description: Blaine Kern in 2005 at Mardi Gras World, the tourist attraction he opened in New Orleans in 1984. Mr. Kern supersized Mardi Gras with the floats he designed; he also enlarged the celebration through tireless promotion and by democratizing it.

item.title: Alabama’s Mud-Slinging Senate Primary
item.description: Welcome to the most negative Senate campaign of 2020 so far.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti
item.media:description: The Senate primary in Alabama between Jeff Sessions and Tommy Tuberville is attracting national attention as it represents the top pickup opportunity for Republicans in the chamber.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: The Trump administration has ordered hospitals to bypass the C.D.C. with key virus data. Critics are sounding alarm bells.
item.dc:creator: Lara Takenaga and Jonathan Wolfe
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

item.title: What It’s Been Like to Vote in 2020 So Far
item.description: Long lines. Pizza at the polls. Absentee ballots that never showed up. And that’s just the warm-up to November.
item.dc:creator: Evan Nicole Brown
item.media:credit: Dustin Chambers/Reuters
item.media:description: Waiting to vote at an assisted living facility in Union City, Ga., last month.

item.title: Abraham Vega, 48, ‘Peacemaking’ Texas Sheriff, Dies
item.description: Remarried, likely to win re-election in November, he was embarking on a second act when he died of the novel coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts

item.title: Dunford Bows Out of Search for Virus Oversight Chair, Leaving it Leaderless
item.description: Three months after Congress created a bipartisan oversight board to scrutinize the handling of hundreds of billions of dollars in pandemic relief, it remains hobbled by the lack of a chairman.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: General Joseph F. Dunford Jr. was the top choice to chair a coronavirus oversight committee.

item.title: Jay Riffe, Spearfishing King, Is Dead at 82
item.description: He became a champion in sport fishing while in his 20s and went on to found a leading company in the manufacture of spearfishing and diving gear.
item.dc:creator: Tom Mashberg

item.title: University of Texas Won’t Drop Song With Racist History
item.description: “The Eyes of Texas,” once sung at minstrel shows, will remain a campus anthem at the University of Texas at Austin, the school announced on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Maria Cramer
item.media:credit: Erich Schlegel/Getty Images
item.media:description: Fans sang “The Eyes of Texas” before the start of a Texas Longhorns game in 2011.
